Question_Text: Before today, had you heard of AI for driverless cars?
Response_Scale: Yes, Not sure / Prefer not to say, No
Survey_Organisation: Ada Lovelace Institute and The Alan Turing Institute
Notes: Wave two of a nationally representative survey. Data weighted based on official statistics. Cross-sectional design. Response rate: 62%.

Question_Text: Have you had any personal experience with using large language models for the following tasks: Search for answers/recommendations?
Response_Scale: Yes, regularly, Yes, a few times, Not sure / Prefer not to say, No, but I am open to using it, No, and I don’t want to
Survey_Organisation: Ada Lovelace Institute and The Alan Turing Institute
Notes: Wave two of a nationally representative survey. Sample representative across age, sex, income, education and ethnicity, with oversampling for low digital skills, lower incomes, and Black/Asian ethnicities. Data weighted based on official statistics. Cross-sectional design. Response rate: 62%. Two-fifths (40%) of the UK public have used LLMs for one or more of the tasks asked about. Usage figures may be a conservative estimate due to existing integration of AI in some search engines.

Response_Scale: Yes, regularly, Yes, a few times, Not sure / Prefer not to say, No, but I am open to using it, No, and I don’t want to
Survey_Organisation: Ada Lovelace Institute and The Alan Turing Institute
Notes: Wave two of a nationally representative survey. Sample representative across age, sex, income, education and ethnicity, with oversampling for low digital skills, lower incomes, and Black/Asian ethnicities. Data weighted based on official statistics. Cross-sectional design. Response rate: 62%. Two-fifths (40%) of the UK public have used LLMs for one or more of the tasks asked about. Usage figures may be a conservative estimate due to existing integration of AI in some search engines.

Question_Text: Have you had any personal experience with using large language models for the following tasks: Supporting job applications?
Response_Scale: Yes, regularly, Yes, a few times, Not sure / Prefer not to say, No, but I am open to using it, No, and I don’t want to
Survey_Organisation: Ada Lovelace Institute and The Alan Turing Institute
Notes: Wave two of a nationally representative survey. Sample representative across age, sex, income, education and ethnicity, with oversampling for low digital skills, lower incomes, and Black/Asian ethnicities. Data weighted based on official statistics. Cross-sectional design. Response rate: 62%. Two-fifths (40%) of the UK public have used LLMs for one or more of the tasks asked about. Those with fewer digital skills and those on lower incomes are slightly more likely to be closed off to the use of LLMs for all tasks, with this difference being statistically significant. For example, of those not open to using general-purpose LLMs for supporting job applications, 27% do not have basic digital skills and 39% have low incomes (equivalised monthly household income of £1,500 or less). This is in contrast with those that have used LLMs for supporting job applications, or are open to using them for this, where only 16% do not have basic digital skills and 33% have low incomes.

Question_Text: To what extent do you think that the use of facial recognition for policing will be beneficial?
Response_Scale: Very beneficial, Fairly beneficial, Not very beneficial, Not at all beneficial, Don’t know / Prefer not to say
Survey_Organisation: Ada Lovelace Institute and The Alan Turing Institute
Notes: Wave two of a nationally representative survey. Sample representative across age, sex, income, education and ethnicity, with oversampling for low digital skills, lower incomes, and Black/Asian ethnicities. Data weighted based on official statistics. Cross-sectional design. Response rate: 62%. People on lower incomes and those with fewer digital skills are less likely than the general public to perceive nearly all of the AI technologies asked about as beneficial.

Question_Text: To what extent do you think that you disagreed with the typical AI researcher about when High-Level Machine Intelligence (HLMI) would exist?
Response_Scale: Not much, A moderate amount, A lot
Notes: One meta question asked to what extent they thought that they disagreed with the typical AI researcher about when HLMI would exist.

Question_Text: Did the second half of the time you had spent working in your area of AI see more progress than the first half?
Response_Scale: First half faster, About the same, Second half faster
Notes: The median time working in the area was 5 years. N_Respondents for this specific question was not specified in the document.

Question_Text: How likely do you find this argument to be broadly correct? (If AI systems do nearly all research and development, improvements in AI will accelerate the pace of technological progress, including further progress in AI. Over a short period (less than 5 years), this feedback loop could cause technological progress to become more than an order of magnitude faster.)
Response_Scale: Quite likely (0-20%), Likely (21-40%), About even chance (41-60%), Unlikely (61-80%), Quite unlikely (81-100%)
Notes: A majority of respondents have thought that it’s either 'quite likely,' 'likely,' or an 'about even chance' that technological progress becomes more than an order of magnitude faster within 5 years of HLMI being achieved.

Question_Text: For typical state-of-the-art AI systems in 2028, do you think it will be possible for users to know the true reasons for systems making a particular choice? By “true reasons” we mean the AI correctly explains its internal decision-making process in a way humans can understand. By “true reasons” we do NOT mean the decision itself is correct.
Response_Scale: Very unlikely (<10%), Unlikely (10-40%), Even odds (40-60%), Likely (60-90%), Very likely (>90%)
Notes: Most respondents considered it unlikely that users of AI systems in 2028 will be able to know the true reasons for the AI systems’ choices, with only 20% giving it better than even odds.

Question_Text: Assume for the purpose of this question that High-Level Machine Intelligence (HLMI) will at some point exist. How positive or negative do you expect the overall impact of this to be on humanity, in the long run? Please answer by saying how probable you find the following kinds of impact, with probabilities adding to 100%.
Response_Scale: Extremely good (e.g. rapid growth in human flourishing), On balance good, More or less neutral, On balance bad, Extremely bad (e.g. human extinction)
Notes: Respondents exhibited diverse views on the expected goodness/badness of HLMI; 64% assigned non-zero probabilities to both extremely good and extremely bad scenarios. Mean probabilities are used for agreement/neutral/disagreement.

Question_Text: To what extent do you think people’s concerns about future risks from AI are due to misunderstandings of AI research?
Response_Scale: Almost entirely, To a large extent, Somewhat, Not much, Hardly at all
Notes: This may reflect a view amongst AI researchers that the general public misunderstands AI.

Question_Text: What rate of global AI progress over the next five years would make you feel most optimistic for humanity’s future? Assume any change in speed affects all projects equally.
Response_Scale: Much slower, Somewhat slower, Current speed, Somewhat faster, Much faster
Notes: There was disagreement about whether faster or slower global AI progress over the next five years would be best for humanity’s future. N_Respondents for this specific question was not specified in the document.

Question_Text: How much should society prioritize AI safety research, relative to how much it is currently prioritized?
Response_Scale: Much less, Less, About the same, More, Much more
Notes: A large majority of respondents thought that AI safety research should be prioritized more than it currently is. Results from two slightly different question framings were combined as the difference was not significant.

Question_Text: Do you think this argument points at an important problem? (Stuart Russell’s argument: with advanced AI, “you get exactly what you ask for, not what you want”)
Response_Scale: Among the most important problems in the field, Very important problem, Moderately important problem, Not an important problem, Not a real problem
Notes: The majority of respondents said that the alignment problem is either a “very important problem” (41%) or “among the most important problems in the field” (13%). N_Respondents for this specific question was not specified in the document.

Question_Text: How valuable is it to work on this problem today, compared to other problems in AI? (Stuart Russell’s alignment problem)
Response_Scale: Much more valuable, More valuable, As valuable, Less valuable, Much less valuable
Notes: Respondents did not generally think that it is more valuable to work on the alignment problem today than other problems. N_Respondents for this specific question was not specified in the document.

Question_Text: How hard do you think this problem is, compared to other problems in AI? (Stuart Russell’s alignment problem)
Response_Scale: Much harder, Harder, As hard, Easier, Much easier
Notes: The majority of respondents said the it is “harder” (36%) or “much harder” (21%) than other problems in AI. N_Respondents for this specific question was not specified in the document.

Question_Text: How much would you support/oppose pausing the development of large-scale Al systems for at least 6 months worldwide?
Response_Scale: Strongly support, Support, Slightly support, Neither support nor oppose, Slightly oppose, Oppose, Strongly oppose, Don't know / no opinion
Notes: Online poll, poststratified to be representative of the US population. Conducted via Prolific participant pool. Agreement combines 'Strongly support', 'Support', and 'Slightly support'. Disagreement combines 'Slightly oppose', 'Oppose', and 'Strongly oppose'. 'Don't know / no opinion' was 4% and is not included in the Neutral percentage.

Question_Text: Do you think Al should be regulated by a federal agency (similarly to how the FDA regulates the approval of drugs and medical devices)?
Response_Scale: Yes, Lean yes, Lean no, No, Don't know / No opinion
Notes: Online poll, poststratified to be representative of the US population. Conducted via Prolific participant pool. Agreement combines 'Yes' and 'Lean yes'. Disagreement combines 'Lean no' and 'No'. Neutral is 'Don't know / No opinion'.

Question_Text: In your daily life, how much do you worry about the negative effects Al could have on your life or on society more broadly?
Response_Scale: Nearly all the time, A lot, A fair amount, Only a little bit, Not at all
Notes: Online poll, poststratified to be representative of the US population. Conducted via Prolific participant pool. Agreement combines 'Nearly all the time', 'A lot', and 'A fair amount' (representing 'worrying a fair amount or more'). Disagreement combines 'Only a little bit' and 'Not at all' (representing 'worrying only a little bit or not at all'). There was no explicit neutral option.

Question_Text: How likely do you think Al is to cause the end of the human race within the next 10 years?
Response_Scale: Extremely likely, Highly likely, Moderately likely, Only slightly likely, Not at all likely, Don't know / No opinion
Notes: Online poll, poststratified to be representative of the US population. Conducted via Prolific participant pool. Agreement combines 'Extremely likely', 'Highly likely', and 'Moderately likely'. Disagreement combines 'Only slightly likely' and 'Not at all likely'. Neutral is 'Don't know / No opinion'.

Question_Text: How likely do you think Al is to cause the end of the human race within the next 50 years?
Response_Scale: Extremely likely, Highly likely, Moderately likely, Only slightly likely, Not at all likely, Don't know / No opinion
Notes: Online poll, poststratified to be representative of the US population. Conducted via Prolific participant pool. Agreement combines 'Extremely likely', 'Highly likely', and 'Moderately likely'. Disagreement combines 'Only slightly likely' and 'Not at all likely'. Neutral is 'Don't know / No opinion'.

Question_Text: How likely do you think it is that Al will eventually become more intelligent than people?
Response_Scale: It already is more intelligent than people, Extremely likely, Highly likely, Moderately likely, Only slightly likely, Not at all likely, Don't know / No opinion
Notes: Online poll, poststratified to be representative of the US population. Conducted via Prolific participant pool. Agreement combines 'It already is more intelligent than people', 'Extremely likely', 'Highly likely', and 'Moderately likely'. Disagreement combines 'Only slightly likely' and 'Not at all likely'. Neutral is 'Don't know / No opinion'.

Question_Text: Do you think Al will do more harm than good?
Response_Scale: Do much more good than harm, Do more good than harm, Do slightly more good than harm, Neutral, Do slightly more harm than good, Do more harm than good, Do much more harm than good, Don't know / No opinion
Notes: Online poll, poststratified to be representative of the US population. Conducted via Prolific participant pool. Agreement combines 'Do much more good than harm', 'Do more good than harm', and 'Do slightly more good than harm'. Disagreement combines 'Do slightly more harm than good', 'Do more harm than good', and 'Do much more harm than good'. 'Neutral' is a distinct response option. 'Don't know / No opinion' was 2% and is not included in the Neutral percentage.

Question_Text: How likely or unlikely do you think it is that a human extinction event will strike in your lifetime?
Response_Scale: Very likely, Somewhat likely, Somewhat unlikely, Very unlikely, Don't know
Notes: Sample size is 2076 adults in GB.

Question_Text: If a human extinction event were to occur, do you think it is more likely to be a result of **technology** (e.g. artificial intelligence or nuclear weaponry), or an **environmental cause** (e.g. climate change or an asteroid)?
Response_Scale: Technology, An environmental cause, Don't know
Notes: Sample size is 2076 adults in GB.

Question_Text: Do you think the government should or should not be developing realistic contingency plans for Robots / artificial intelligence?
Response_Scale: Should be developing a contingency plan, Should **not** be developing a contingency plan, Don't know
Notes: Sample size is 2076 adults in GB.

Question_Text: Do you agree or disagree that 'Overall, artificial intelligence (AI) creates more problems than it solves?'
Response_Scale: Agree, Disagree
Notes: Australians 16+, Weighted results. Conducted in conjunction with the Campaign for AI Safety.

Question_Text: Do you believe artificial intelligence (AI) presents a risk of human extinction in the next two decades?
Response_Scale: Yes, No
Notes: Australians 16+, Weighted results. Conducted in conjunction with the Campaign for AI Safety.
